text: I'm John Harwood with the New York Times
and CNBC here on the floor of the
democratic national convention at the
Pepsi Center in Denver with governor
bill Ritter of Colorado which not only
is the host state for this convention
but one of the key states in the general
election campaign governor Larry start
by asking you we see in the polls that
it's a very very close race in Colorado
who are the voters who are going to
decide this race between Obama and
McCain where do they live and what is it
going to be on is it personal factors
about the nominees or is it issues and
if so which ones they are independent
voters and I would say even moderate
Republican voters they live throughout
the state but concentrated in the
suburban counties and particularly well
even in larimer county which is around
the fort collins area in northern
Colorado but really in Jefferson and
arapahoe county they are people who are
registered independent so that it can
vote for the person we've seen this
dramatic swing from really Republicans
dominating almost every aspect of
political leadership in Colorado to now
Democrats dominating almost every aspect
of it the way we've been successful is
by really appealing to them as the
centrist this pragmatist willing to
tackle big problems saying we have a
different energy future we're a big oil
and gas state but that doesn't mean we
should have let a renewables go untapped
and so we're creating this economy we
call the new energy economy Barack Obama
kind of comes out and makes a message to
those independent voters about how he
creates jobs about how he describes a
different energy future I think at the
end the day he wins like we've been
winning in the West we had a lieutenant
governor who was african-american
elected in the 70s in Colorado and I
really do think that being comfortable
from the perspective of Barack Obama's
you know african-american ethnicity is
not such an issue I think people need
who don't know him absolutely need to
get comfortable that he has a real sense
about middle-class working families
struggle and if I think he can
communicate and his messages there if
they listen to him and he's able to
resonate with them then again it's those
independent voters and suburban areas
that want to know he understands the the
middle class he understands what they
care about he's got a real way to
address it one of the things that has
helped make you successful in Colorado
is you've gotten significant support
from the business community Obama has in
fundraising so far but some raised
questions about his tax policies he
would raise taxes on capital gain
and dividends on high-income Americans
how do you think Barack Obama can make
the business community in Colorado which
has some effect on political outcomes go
to Barack Obama side rather than John
McCain well I think it's such a broad
perspective it's not just about you know
business issues it's about how do you
really get the economy going and the
business community Colorado they care a
great deal about my business policies
but they also care about education and
as a nation as a nation we are losing
our edge our competitive edge the next
president has to address it but has to
address it with reform policies not just
slogans not just you know simple ways of
thinking about it and I think Barack
Obama again can appeal to the business
community in a broader way thinking
about that I know tax policy is
important so his message has to he has
to be clear about what he's going to do
but at the end of the day also just
investment in infrastructure and
education of things that the business
community cares about and that he cares
about energy is a huge issue in the
election nationally it's been a big part
of your governorship when I've seen what
you've had to say about energy you say
nuclear's a part of it wind and solar a
part of it biofuels and other renewables
are part of it but that sounds and also
coal as well cleaner coal technology
that sounds a little bit like John
McCain's all of the above energy policy
where do you distinguish Obama and
McCain on that front because if you look
at it Obama is also talking about
creating an economy around it he talks
about the need to put a million hybrids
on the streets by 2015 and to make sure
those are American jobs where you create
that economy and I think that's
absolutely important and it looked at
his energy policy the way he's talking
about meshing climate is an issue with
energy policy and in creating an economy
around it that's been our three legs of
the stool if you will and Barack Obama
is there so you know John McCain has
reversed position on a lot of things
that have to do with energy can't go
into all of them right now but they
people need to understand that and what
you could get is four more years of just
George Bush's policies which have been
drill drill drill drill and they've been
failed they failed strategies we've
missed great opportunities if you agree
that drilling is not the entire answer
to the problem do you agree with McCain
that it's
part of the answer well I I do but I'd
have to make this caveat because we're
here in Colorado the federal government
is trying right now to write the rules
for commercial leasing for oil shale
this is part of their drill drill drill
strategy we're nowhere near writing the
rules for that because the company's
doing the RD&D they can't say what the
impact is on on water they can't say
what the impact is on air or with a
where they get the energy to use the
technology that they're presently doing
so that's an example of not not wholly
endorsing the government's sort of drill
drill drill strategy there may be a
great reason for looking at offshore
drilling but it is not about oil shale
in Colorado until we know the impact the
environmental impacts on trying to tap
that shale you've got your convention
this week John McCain has his in
Minnesota next week all indications are
that this thing is closed and may be
closed for a while when is this election
going to break and you're going to get
we're going to get a clear indication of
where Colorado's going where the country
school I think mid-september I really do
think there will be a couple bumps
coming out of the convention and then
after that you know a week or two weeks
maybe before their their first dual
appearance interestingly in Colorado we
vote early so the first opportunity to
vote will be after October fifth so both
candidates and I would really say you
know my candidate Barack Obama he's got
to make this case in September in
October to erm sorry in September to the
voters who were going to vote early
there's a lot of seniors that vote early
and that's a really important
constituency in Colorado for Barack
Obama how would you rate his odds of
carrying your state well I think they're
very very good I really believe because
of our 350 no I think they're better
than that because of our experiences
here in the last four years and being
able to appeal like I said to
independence and even to moderate
Republicans who are really i think
disenfranchised with what their party is
now governor thanks so much for joining
us thank you
